Expectation1: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation1: A pilot declares low fuel on approach and needs immediate vectors to the nearest runway.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A monthly food drive for the local homeless shelter is scheduled to take place at the convent today.
Story: I sit in the control tower, headset pressed to my ear, eyes darting between radar screens. The voice of a pilot crackles through, tense and urgent—he’s low on fuel, needs immediate vectors. My training kicks in, every muscle taut with focus. I know lives depend on my calm, precise instructions. But as I guide him, my phone vibrates in my pocket. It’s a reminder: the food drive at the convent starts in ten minutes. Sister Agnes and the others are counting on me to help serve meals to the homeless, to be present in our community’s hour of need. I feel the weight of my habit beneath my uniform, the cross at my neck a silent reminder of my vows. My heart pounds with the pressure of two worlds—one demanding unwavering attention to the skies, the other calling me to serve with compassion on the ground. I stare at the radar, torn, the expectations of both roles pressing in, each urgent, each vital, and I feel myself caught in the impossible space between them.
